awd_titl_txt: MPWR 2016 and beyond: Fostering sustainable networks for women in RUME
awd_abstract_narration:
Women in RUME are mathematicians whose research expertise is in undergraduate education rather than one of the more traditional areas of mathematics. In general, these women tend to hold academic positions in departments of mathematical sciences, where they can face some systemic barriers and professional challenges that can make them feel marginalized. Toward addressing this issue, this project will build on an infrastructure initiated and cultivated in prior work: a face-to-face mentoring and partnership system that targets participation amongst women researchers within undergraduate mathematics education. This infrastructure has become known as MPWR: Mentoring and Partnerships for Women in RUME. The project will include support for this infrastructure for an additional three years. What's more, after the previous two annual iterations, the MPWR infrastructure is sufficiently established to be studied as a model to support women in undergraduate STEM education research.

The positioning of women in RUME in mathematics departments compounds multiple known issues -- such as women in academia, women in mathematics, education researchers in mathematics departments, more specifically, RUME experts in mathematics departments -- exacerbating the potential for marginalization. Studying this situation in order to advance understanding, the project will pursue the following research questions: (1) What are the issues that women in RUME struggle with related to career success, and more specifically, what impedes women in RUME from social and academic integration into their research community? (2) How do these issues compare to (a) men in RUME, (b) women in mathematics research, (c) women in other areas of mathematics education research, and (d) women in educational research in general? (3) In what ways do the MPWR seminar impact the RUME community, specifically focusing on three groups: women in RUME, including (a) those who have participated in MPWR and (b) women who have not participated in MPWR, and (c) men in RUME? (4) In what ways does the MPWR seminar support the social and academic integration of women in RUME?

por.por_cntn:
The disproportionately low number of women in STEM fields in academia at all stages of a career is well documented (e.g., Hill et al., 2010; Mason & Goulden, 2002; NSB, 2010). The role of mentoring, both vertically and laterally, in bringing (and keeping) more women in these positions is also well documented (Beede et al., 2011; Kahveci, Southerland, & Gilmer, 2006; Mavriplis et al., 2005) but underutilized (Preston, 2004). The Mentoring and Partnerships for Women in Research in Undergraduate Mathematics Education (RUME) Seminar, known as the MPWR Seminar, was created to address this need in that community for increased support and mentorship.

The MPWR Seminar was a one-day meeting held the day before and in the same location as the Annual RUME Conference. This seminar consisted of panel discussions led by women in the RUME community and beyond (such as in the broader mathematics education community and from other Discipline Based Education Research (DBER) communities), group discussions between the panelists and MPWR participants, and formal/informal networking opportunities between participants and speakers.

The MPWR Seminar began in 2014 (DUE-1352990, DUE-1457785) and was motivated by the experiences of women in the RUME community and the literature surrounding women in academia and women in STEM.  One overarching goal for MPWR was to support networks of women in academic positions in undergraduate mathematics education, including tenure-track and tenured positions, as well as positions in the private sector and professional organizations. A second overarching goal was to uniquely support women in the RUME community in creating and sustaining successful careers as researchers in the field of undergraduate mathematics education.

There were seven MPWR Seminars from 2014-2020. Due to the pandemic, there was not a RUME Conference nor an MPWR Seminar in 2021. In 2022, the remaining funds were used to provide registration scholarships for the 2022 RUME Conference to past MPWR participants who did not have other funding sources to attend the conference.

Based on participant requests for smaller structured networking groups, MPWRment groups were initiated in 2015. These optional groups of 4-6 women each were organized by career stage and were tasked with keeping in touch with each other throughout the year and supporting each other's careers in various ways. Many of these groups continued to meet regularly for many years, some even supporting each other in ways such as attending each other?s dissertation defenses and conference presentations.  

In total, there were 60-82 participants in the MPWR Seminar each year (see Table).  As intended, many attended multiple seminars, for a total of 251 unique participants over the seven years. In 2019 and 2020, virtual participation was also an option. Each year, the participants represented various career stages.  For instance, in 2020, there were 30 Students, 16 Assistant Professors, 18 Associate Professors, 6 Full Professors, 2 Postdocs, 3 lecturers, and 7 from other positions.

Each year, there were a variety of panels and workshop. The panels and associated discussions had 3-4 speakers and all participants attended; the workshops had 1-2 facilitators each, and the participants could choose which to attend. At first, the panels and workshops were often led by more senior women in the field based an invitation from the Seminar leadership. Over time, the panels and workshops were created based on participant suggestions with participant leadership across the career stages.  See the Table for a summary of the various panel and workshop topics over the seven years of the MPWR Seminar.
